channel.title: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?
channel.description:
Title.
Popular ones I know are:
ArchLinux Ubuntu LinuxMint Kbuntu

item.title: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?
item.dc:creator: @K-style K-style
item.description:
@K-style wrote:

Kbuntu

Read full topic
item.source: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?

item.title: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:33, topic:546562”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=665461.msg4452110#msg4452110 date=1412283880]

[quote author=whattehp406 link=topic=665461.msg4452090#msg4452090 date=1412274055]

[quote author=Niall link=topic=665461.msg4452055#msg4452055 date=1412249583]

CentOS anyone? [size=8pt]please…[/size]

I don’t know why you’d bother with CentOS over Fedora, unless you’re talking about headless servers.
[/quote]Yeah, only use it for servers. Desktop linux is neat and i used Ubuntu before but it just doesn’t stack up against windows for me. Most engineering software isn’t available for linux and i cba to dual boot just for that.
[/quote] There’s nothing too special about CentOS even as a server distro.[/quote]

Well, other than it being based on RHEL, having a ridiculously long support cycle (CentOS 7 is being supported until June 2024) and having damn near everything support it, sure, nothing too special about CentOS as a server that can’t be done on another distro.[/quote]I don’t really prefer RHEL over anything else but that support cycle is pretty impressive. I didn’t know that, thanks.

Read full topic
item.source: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?

item.dc:creator: @peterbjornx peterbjornx
item.description:
@peterbjornx wrote:

debian (whichever is “stable” at the time of install), i prefer to use LXDE on my slower systems and gnome classic on my dev box when I need a gui, most of the time I don’t need a GUI I use dvtm + bash

item.title: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:32, topic:546562”][quote author=whattehp406 link=topic=665461.msg4452090#msg4452090 date=1412274055]

[quote author=Niall link=topic=665461.msg4452055#msg4452055 date=1412249583]

CentOS anyone? [size=8pt]please…[/size]

I don’t know why you’d bother with CentOS over Fedora, unless you’re talking about headless servers.
[/quote]Yeah, only use it for servers. Desktop linux is neat and i used Ubuntu before but it just doesn’t stack up against windows for me. Most engineering software isn’t available for linux and i cba to dual boot just for that.
[/quote] There’s nothing too special about CentOS even as a server distro.[/quote]

Well, other than it being based on RHEL, having a ridiculously long support cycle (CentOS 7 is being supported until June 2024) and having damn near everything support it, sure, nothing too special about CentOS as a server that can’t be done on another distro.

Read full topic
item.source: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?

item.title: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“whattehp406, post:31, topic:546562”][quote author=Niall link=topic=665461.msg4452055#msg4452055 date=1412249583]

CentOS anyone? [size=8pt]please…[/size]

I don’t know why you’d bother with CentOS over Fedora, unless you’re talking about headless servers.
[/quote]Yeah, only use it for servers. Desktop linux is neat and i used Ubuntu before but it just doesn’t stack up against windows for me. Most engineering software isn’t available for linux and i cba to dual boot just for that.[/quote] There’s nothing too special about CentOS even as a server distro. I guess one advantage is its popularity, which means a lot of support and documentation. I could get what I needed done faster with an Ubuntu server, and also the ability to upgrade.

Read full topic

item.title: Which flavor of Linux do you prefer?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

I currently am running a somewhat custom build of lubuntu. Swapped out much of the distributed packages with lighter versions, and updated kernel so that it would run better on the Acer C720 Chromebook lol. At idle I am usually around 2-3% CPU so I guess thats good.

Read full topic
